FacilityName: American Gypsum Company, Inc. - Duke, Oklahoma
FacilityStr1: Hwy 62 West (1/4 mile west of Duke)

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Nonmetallic Mineral Mining and Quarrying

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This facility is regulated under Program 2 requirements under 40 CFR
68.10 because:
       It stores propane in excess of the threshold quantity
       A release from this facility could impact an offsite public 
receptor(business)
       It does not operate under a NAICS code specified in the rule
       It is not subject to OSHA PSM

40 CFR Part 68 Subpart G applies to an owner or operator of a 
stationary source that has more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance in a process, as determined under 40 CFR 68.115.  American Gypsum stores more than the threshold quantity of propane (10,000 pounds) for use as fuel at an industrial facility.  Therefore, American Gypsum is required to submit a Risk Management Plan (RMP) as defined in 40 CFR 68.150.

American Gypsum is committed to operating in a safe and compliant manner. Employees involved in operating the propane storage facility are thoroughly trained to identify and understand the hazards posed by this the transfer process.  Process safety and emergency response materials are kept on site and periodically reviewed.  Information includes information pertaining to the hazards of propane, process technology, process equipment, and emergency response procedures.

The stationary source is the propane storage facility.  The largest propane process group (e.g., storage tank or group of interconnected tanks) has a storage capacity of 30,000 water gallons (110,000 pounds).  The total propane 
stationary storage capacity is 220,000 pounds.

The facility is required to complete one worst-case release scenario 
per hazardous substance handled [68.165(a)(2)] to determine program 
applicability.  American Gypsum has chosen to use the Vapor Cloud Explosion (TNT) model to determine offsite impacts.  For this facility, a worst-case 
release would occur in the event that the largest propane storage 
tank(s) would rupture and the entire contents would be released to the 
atmosphere in 10 minutes.

Results of Worst-Case Pr

opane Release Scenario

Input of the preceding data into the RMP Comp program, the results 
indicate a worst-case impact of  0..39 miles for the facility.  The rule 
defines the explosive endpoint of propane to be 1 psi overpressure.  
The residential population within a 0.39 mile radius of the facility is 
6 based on the 2000 US Census data.

The facility is required to complete one alternate release scenario per 
regulated chemical per 40 CFR Part 68.165(a)(2).  The alternative 
release scenario considered is in accordance with the guidelines 
provided in 40 CFR 68.22 and 68.28.

The alternative scenarios chosen for this facility involves a release 
because of a sudden split in the hose during transfer.  While this 
scenario is still unlikely because the transfer hoses used have 
multiple layers of rubber and a layer of braided stainless steel wire 
underneath the outer sheath (to prevent abrasions, cuts, and splits) it 
is more likely than the worst-case as required by 40 CFR 68.28(b)(i).  
This scenario is also the
most likely to occur, since overfilling is prevented by a return vapor 
line to the tank truck making the delivery.  The transfer hose rupture 
area is assumed at 0.5 square inches.  Because personnel are always 
present at the facility during transfer, Battle Creek Co-op personnel 
will respond within 10 minutes.  Release rate was calculated using the 
OCAG tank release equation (Section 8.1.1).

Results of Propane Alternative Release Scenario

Input of the preceding data into the RMP Comp program, the results 
indicate an alternate case impact of 0.08 miles for the facility.  The 
residential population within this radius is 0.
 
The facility maintains written process safety information to enable 
employees involved in handling propane to identify and understand the 
hazards posed by this process.  Written information includes physical 
properties of propane, health risks associated with propane exposure, 
and material safety data sheets.  In additi

on, the facility has 
conducted and/or implemented the following:
          
             hazards review
             standard operating procedures
             training program
             maintenance program
             compliance audits
             incident investigation     

American Gypsum has had no recordable accidents involving propane within the past five years. 
         
Recommendations for safety improvements were identified in the hazard 
review which was completed January 9, 2004.  Recommendations were 
identified for two categories: Standard Operating Procedures, and 
Training.  Safety improvements will be investigated concerning their 
impacts on other systems and/or procedures prior to implementation.  
Additional recommendations may be made upon review of any accidents 
and/or when the hazard review is updated every five years.
